line_1: My fondness I, or you your power derive; —
line_2: But my affection will your scorn survive!

line_1: And all his blithsome tales their praise derive
line_2: His tuneless numbers hardly now survive,

line_1: And from his sweet'ning art derive
line_2: A better scent than when alive.

line_1: And hence they surest confidence derive.

line_2: " The choicest sweets that store the hive:

line_1: Does he from heav'n or earth his hopes derive?
line_2: From saints departed? or from priests alive?

line_1: And as from us their Being they derive,
line_2: They back again should all due Homage give.

line_1: "Whether, O Friend of Art! your gems derive
line_2: Fine forms from Greece, and fabled Gods revive;

line_1: And not from Towns, but Provinces derive.
line_2: So Douglass, Mar and Southerland survive,
From the most noted whore alive;

line_1: From thee alone my being I derive,
line_2: One beauteous smile from thee, makes all my hopes alive.
